questions.text: Which of the following drains into the IVC?
questions.explanation:
Tributaries of IVC

Key features

Right and left 3rd and 4th lumbar veins

It drains the posterior, lateral, and anterior abdominal walls into IVC.

Right gonadal vein

Left gonadal vein drains into the left renal vein, which drains into the inferior vena cava.

Right suprarenal vein

Left suprarenal vein drains into the left renal vein, which drains into the inferior vena cava.

Right inferior phrenic vein

Left inferior phrenic vein drains into the left suprarenal, or left renal vein.

Right and left renal veins

Left renal vein (7.5cm) is three times longer than right renal vein (2.5cm)

Hepatic veins

Three large and many small veins open directly into the anterior surface of the inferior vena cava just before it pierces the diaphragm.

questions.text: A 14 year old male presents with a mushroom like tumor in the distal femur for the past 2 years. Which of the following features suggest its malignant transformation?

options.label: B
options.text: Bone marrow is continuous with the parent bone

options.label: C
options.text: The cartilaginous growth goes towards the joint

questions.explanation:
Description
  • Also known as Exostosis
  • Most common primary benign bone tumor (but not a true bone tumor)
  • Benign cartilaginous neoplasms arising from physeal cartilage beneath the periosteum.
  • More common in males, usually appearing during adolescence.
  • Affects long bones, lower end of femur > upper end of tibia

Types
  • Solitary Osteochondroma
  • Multiple Osteochondromas (MO)

Clinical features
  • Painless mass- most common presentation
  • Pain: secondary to bursa formation/fracture/nerve compression

Radiographic Appearance
  • X-ray: Pedunculated cauliflower-like mass originating from metaphysis
  • MRI: used to assess cartilage thickness

Malignant transformation
  • Very rare
  • MRI showing cartilage thickness > 2 cms suggests malignant transformation (Option A)

Management
  • Asymptomatic cases: No treatment required
  • Symptomatic cases: Excision with biopsy

questions.text: In the case of an ongoing bleeding in a patient with a fracture of the pelvic bone, what is the immediate action that needs to be taken to address the situation, if the patient is in hypotension?

In the emergency room, a 40-year-old male patient arrived with a complaint of pain and swelling in the right shoulder region following a fall. The patient's X-ray indicates a tear in which of the following ligaments?
questions.explanation:
Description
  • Acute acromioclavicular (AC) joint injury, commonly following direct trauma; includes sprains, subluxations, and dislocations.

Mechanism of Injury
  • Fall on the shoulder with arm adducted leading to ligament strain or tear. Severe forces may cause complete dislocation.

Classification
  • Type I: AC ligament sprain; joint remains undisplaced.
  • Type II: AC ligaments torn; joint subluxated with slight clavicle elevation.
  • Type III: AC and coracoclavicular ligaments torn; joint dislocated, visible step deformity. (Option C)
  • Type IV: Posterior clavicle displacement.
  • Type V: Marked upward clavicle displacement.
  • Type VI: Inferior clavicle displacement beneath the coracoid.

Clinical Features
  • Signs: Pain, bruising, and tenderness at the injury site. Visible ‘step’ in cases of dislocation.
  • Movement: Limited shoulder movement with severe pain in dislocation.

X-ray
  • Views: Anteroposterior, cephalic tilt, and axillary views are recommended. Stress view may differentiate Type II vs Type III.
  • Stress View: Measure the distance between the coracoid and clavicle; >50% difference indicates dislocation.

Treatment
  • Sprains/Subluxations: Rest in a sling, pain subsides within a week, followed by shoulder exercises.
  • Dislocations: Techniques include ligament reconstruction or clavicle excision.
  • Post-surgery Rehab: Elbow/forearm exercises day after surgery, shoulder movements 2 weeks later. Avoid strenuous lifting for 4–6 months.

questions.text: Calculate the anion gap: Na- 145mmol/L K- 4mmol/L Cl- 90mmol/L HCO 3 - 15mmol/L
questions.explanation:
Definition

The difference between the measured cations and the measured anions in the extracellular fluid (ECF).

Cations (Measured)

Sodium (Na⁺) and Potassium (K⁺)

Anions (Measured)

Chloride (Cl⁻) and Bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻)

Unmeasured Anions

Protein anions, sulfate, phosphate, and organic acids.

Reason for Anion Gap

The unmeasured anions cause the difference between the measured cations and anions.

Formula

Anion Gap = (Na⁺ + K⁺) – (Cl⁻ + HCO₃⁻)

Normal Value

~12 mmol/L

questions.text: A neonate is brought to the pediatric ER in acute respiratory distress. On examination, the abdomen is scaphoid. Which of the following should not be performed in this patient?
A farmer presents with fever and physical examination findings as seen in the image. His serum creatinine is 1.4 mg/dL, and platelet count is 88,000/mm³. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Scrub typhus

Causative agent

Orientia tsutsugamushi - It differs from Rickettsia both genetically and by its cell wall composition i.e. it lacks lipopolysaccharide layer.

Vector

Chiggers (larvae of trombiculid mite)

Pathophysiology
  • Scrub typhus is so named because it occurs in areas of scrub vegetation i.e. low lying trees and bushes.
  • It is transmitted by the bite of infected trombiculid mites.
  • Among all stages of mite, the larvae (called chiggers) are the only stage that feed on humans. Hence, scrub typhus is also called chiggerosis.
  • Mites can maintain the organisms through transovarial transmission.
  • Orientia tsutsugamushi infects mononuclear cells but still produces fever and rash.

Clinical features

  • The classic presentation of scrub typhus consists of triad of an eschar (at the site of bite), regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash sparing palms and soles.
  • Non-specific manifestations may appear early such as fever, headache, myalgia, cough, and gastrointestinal symptoms.
  • Complications such as encephalitis and interstitial pneumonia may occur rarely in the late stage (due to vascular injury).

Investigations

The Weil-Felix test shows OX K+ only.

Treatment

  • Doxycycline is the drug choice.
  • Azithromycin is given alternatively and the drug of choice in children and pregnant women.

questions.text: What is the order of the band in the sarcomere?
questions.explanation:
Sarcomere

The functional unit of a myofibril, composed of alternating dark A bands and light I bands.

Z Line

A dense, narrow line that bisects the I band; contains 2 actin molecules.

I Band

The light band alternating with the dark A band; bisected by the Z line.

A Band

The dark band in the sarcomere; includes the central H zone and is composed of thick filaments.

H Zone

The lighter region in the center of the A band.

M Line

The dark line in the middle of the H zone; contains M protein.

A 13-year-old girl presents with fever and retro-orbital headache for 2 days. Her Tourniquet test and NS1 antigen are positive, suggesting Dengue infection. Which of the following findings qualifies as a severe dengue criterion?
questions.explanation:
Uncategorised fever

  • No typical features

Break bone fever

(Classical dengue fever/ acute viral infection)

 
  • Retro orbital pain
  • Arthralgia
  • Severe myalgia and headache
  • Bimodal presentation of fever:
    • 39-40°C, peaks on days 1-2
    • Resurges: day 5-6
    • Recovery: day 7-10.
  • Rash: pin-point eruptions on the face, neck and chest followed by maculopapular or scarlatiniform on 3rd or 4th day.

Dengue haemorrhagic syndrome
  • Dengue fever + hemorrhagic manifestations(bleeding from any orifice)
  • Rash: Maculopapular/ Rubelliform
  • Lab diagnosis
    • 20% increase in hematocrit
    • Thrombocytopenia (<1 lac)
  • Clinical diagnosis
    • Tourniquet test- >10 petechiae/ sq inch area

Dengue shock syndrome
  • Pulse pressure - <20 mmHg
  • Mean systolic pressure - <90mmHg: adults, <80 mmHg: children.

Neurological
  • Dengue encephalopathy is most commonly encountered neurological complication of dengue virus
    • linked primarily to dengue hemorrhagic fever and dengue shock syndrome
    • EEG may show abnormalities such as burst suppression and seizures
    • CSF profiles typically remain normal.
    • Neuroimaging can be normal or reveal diffuse cerebral edema.
  • Encephalitis
  • GBS
  • Stroke

Cardiomyopathy
  • Dengue virus-induced dilated cardiomyopathy should always be considered if a dengue fever patient has refractory shock and signs and symptoms of congestive heart failure.

Hepatic injury
  • Liver involvement in dengue is a crucial feature
  • The effect ranges from an asymptomatic rise in liver enzymes to the development of ALF
  • The most common atypical manifestation reported was hepatitis

Pneumonia

 
  • Staphylococcus pneumonia is an important accompanying problem seen in dengue patient
  • co-infection between dengue and influenza can result in exacerbation of pneumonia

Orchitis

 
  • Orchitis usually occurs together with epididymitis
  • Commonly seen in men between 14 and 35 years of age.

Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever

All of the following:

  • Acute onset of fever
  • 2-7 days duration
  • Hemorrhagic manifestations
    • Positive tourniquet test/Petechiae
    • Ecchymosis
    • Purpura/Bleeding from mucosa, GIT, Injection sites, etc
  • Platelet count ≤ 100,000 cells/cu.mm.
  • Plasma leakage
    • Rising hematocrit
      • Hemoconcentration >20%
    • Pleural effusion, ascites/Hypoproteinemia)

Dengue Shock Syndrome
  • DHF criteria plus Signs of Shock
  • Tachycardia/Cool extremities/Weak pulse/Lethargy/Restlessness
  • Pulse pressure <20 mm Hg with increased Diastolic pressure (e.g. 100/80)
  • Hypotension (Systolic <80 mm Hg for age <5 years/80-90 mm Hg for older children and adults)

questions.text: An 18-day-old baby presents with fever and cough. On examination, vesicles are observed over the trunk and upper limb. The mother had genital ulcers one year ago, which have since resolved. Biopsy of the vesicles reveals multinucleated giant cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
EBV (Epstein Barr virus)

  • Downey cells: Atypical lymphocytes (large, vacuolated) are observed.
  • Ballerina skirt appearance.

CMV (Cytomegalovirus)

  • The presence of inclusion bodies gives the characteristic “Owl-eye appearance”.

HHV 8 (human herpes virus type 8)

  • Castleman disease: Onion skinning of lymphocytes and blood vessels, giving the appearance of “Lollipop follicles”.

questions.text: Glycogen phosphorylase is activated by?
Which of the following viral infections has the least teratogenicity?
questions.explanation:
Vertical transmission of diseases.

1st trimester

Rubella, Chickenpox/varicella

2nd trimester

Parvovirus

3rd trimester

Toxoplasmosis, CMV, Hepatitis B and Syphilis.

During delivery

HIV and herpes

Infection

Pathogen & Transmission

Clinical Features

Toxoplasmosis

Toxoplasma gondii (transplacental from infected mother, cat feces, undercooked meat)

Classic triad: chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications; anemia, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, seizures, intellectual disability

Varicella

(Option B ruled out)

Varicella-zoster virus (aerosols, direct contact, transplacental)

Congenital varicella syndrome: skin lesions, limb hypoplasia, neurodevelopmental delay

Syphilis

Treponema pallidum (sexual transmission, transplacental, peripartum)

Stillbirth, Hutchinson triad (notched teeth, interstitial keratitis, deafness), skeletal abnormalities

Parvovirus B19

Parvovirus B19 (respiratory droplets, transplacental)

Hydrops fetalis, neurodevelopmental defects, fetal anemia

Rubella

(Option D ruled out)

Rubella virus (respiratory droplets, transplacental)

Congenital rubella syndrome: sensorineural deafness, cataracts, congenital heart disease, hepatosplenomegaly

Cytomegalovirus (CMV)

(Option A ruled out)

CMV (body fluids, blood transfusion, organ transplant, transplacental, peripartum, breast milk)

Leading cause of non-genetic congenital hearing loss, petechiae, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, neurodevelopmental deficits

Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV-1 & HSV-2)

HSV (direct contact, mucosal exposure, peripartum)

Neonatal herpes: vesicular rash, encephalitis, seizures, bulging fontanelle, viral sepsis, organ failure

questions.text: What happens to chloride levels in sweat and pancreatic secretions in cystic fibrosis?

questions.explanation:

Autosomal recessive disorder.

Genetic Cause

Mutations in the CFTR gene (cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator).

CFTR Function

Symptoms

  • Fat maldigestion due to pancreatic exocrine insufficiency.
  • Infertility in males due to abnormal development of the vas deferens.

Diagnostic Feature

Elevated chloride levels in sweat (>60 mmol/L).

questions.text: A 30-year-old women present with upper respiratory tract infection and orbital pain. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Orbital Cellulitis

Definition
  • Orbital cellulitis is an acute infection of the soft tissues of the orbit located behind the orbital septum.

Etiology
  • Exogenous Infection: Occurs due to penetrating injuries. Example: foreign body retention, surgical procedures like evisceration, enucleation, orbitotomy, dacryocystectomy.
  • Endogenous Infection: From metastatic infections. Example: breast abscess, puerperal sepsis, thrombophlebitis, septicemia
  • Extension from Neighboring Structures (most common): Paranasal sinuses (most common: ethmoid sinus), teeth, face, eyelids, intracranial cavity, and intraorbital structures.

Clinical Features

Symptoms:

  • Swelling and severe pain (worsened by eye movement or pressure).
  • Systemic symptoms: fever, nausea, vomiting, prostration.
  • Vision loss and/or diplopia in moderate to advanced cases.

Signs:

  • Swelling of lids with woody hardness and redness.
  • Chemosis (conjunctival swelling), which may lead to necrosis.
  • Axial proptosis.
  • Restricted eye movements.
  • RAPD (Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect) may occur due to optic neuropathy or central retinal artery occlusion.
  • Fundus examination may show retinal vein congestion, papillitis, or papilledema

Staging

Modified Chandler staging system:

  • Stage I: Preseptal cellulitis/ periorbital cellulitis (limited anterior to orbital septum)
  • Stage II: Inflammatory orbital oedema/ Orbital cellulitis (Posterior to orbital septum)
  • Stage III: Subperiosteal abscess
  • Stage IV: Orbital abscess
  • Stage V: Cavernous sinus thrombosis

Investigations
  • Cultures: Nasal, conjunctival, and blood samples for bacterial culture.
  • Complete Blood Count: Leukocytosis.
  • X-ray PNS: To detect sinusitis.
    • Orbital Ultrasonography: To detect orbital abscesses.
  • CT Scan/MRI: Differentiates preseptal from postseptal cellulitis, detects abscesses, intracranial extension, and guides surgical drainage.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with the complaints of vertigo which is sudden in onset, sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL), and tinnitus which lasts minutes to hours with accompanied nausea, vomiting and vagal symptoms. Investigations show there is endolymphatic hypertension present. What is the diagnosis of the patient?
questions.explanation:
Vertigo
  • Episodic with sudden onset
  • Attacks occur in clusters, interspersed with periods of remission accompanied by nausea, vomiting, ataxia & nystagmus.
  • Loud noises might trigger vertigo due to the Tullio phenomenon.

Hearing Loss
  • Fluctuating hearing loss may improve between attacks but may progressively worsen over time, with some degree of permanent hearing loss.
  • Sensorineural hearing loss initially affecting lower frequencies.
  • Patients might experience distorted hearing or Diplacusis

Tinnitus
  • Low-pitched & Roaring type
  • It can be aggravated during acute attacks and might persist during periods of remission

Aural Fullness

Fluctuates & may vary in intensity

Emotional Impact

The recurrent nature of symptoms can lead to emotional stress and apprehension about future attacks, contributing to overall distress.

questions.text: Which of the following is/are advantages of a saline mount compared to an iodine mount in stool microscopy? 1. Motility of trophozoites 2. Internal structure of cysts 3. Differentiate bile stained and non bile stained
questions.explanation:
Stool sample processing

Microscopic examination of stool samples

This is done by two methods:

  • Direct wet mount examination
  • Permanent staining methods

Direct wet mount

Preparation:

  • Drops of saline and Lugol’s iodine are used on the left and right sides of the slide.
  • Mix ~2 mg of feces to form a smooth suspension.
  • Place a coverslip on the mount for examination under a microscope.

Observation:

  • Trophozoites
  • Normal constituents of stool like plant fibers and starch cells can be seen
  • Cellular Elements:
    • Pus cells (in inflammatory diarrhea)
    • Red blood cells (in dysentery)
  • Charcot-Leyden Crystals

 

 

Types of wet mounts:

Saline mount:

  • Uses: Detects trophozoites, cysts, helminth eggs, and larvae.
  • Advantages:
    • Demonstrates motility of trophozoites and larvae.
    • Bile staining property can be assessed (bile-stained eggs appear golden brown).

Iodine mount:

  • Advantages: Better visualization of nuclear details in cysts, larvae, and eggs.
  • Disadvantages:
    • Iodine immobilizes and kills parasites, hindering motility observation.
    • Bile staining property cannot be assessed.

Permanent stained smears

 
  • This method stains the internal structures.
  • Purpose: For accurate detection of protozoan cysts and trophozoites.
  • Common Stains:
    • Iron-hematoxylin stain.
    • Trichrome stain.
    • Modified acid-fast stain for coccidian parasites (e.g., Cryptosporidium).

questions.text: Which bacterial toxin acts by interfering with the function of elongation factor-2 (EF-2)?
questions.explanation:
Diphtheria Toxin

Production and Structure
  • DT is a protein exotoxin produced by the toxigenic Corynebacterium diphtheriae.
  • Consists of two fragments (Bipartite), A and B, with a molecular weight of approximately 62,000 daltons.

Role of Lysogenic β-phage
  • The tox gene is carried by a lysogenic β-phage.
  • Only phage-infected strains produce toxin; nontoxigenic strains can become toxigenic if infected.
  • Corynebacterium diphtheriae remains localized at the infection site, with only the toxin entering circulation, causing toxaemia but not bacteremia.

Mechanism of Action
  • Fragment B binds host cell receptors, facilitating fragment A entry into the cytoplasm.
  • Fragment A catalyses ADP-ribosylation of EF-2, halting protein synthesis.

Systemic Effects
  • DT spreads via blood, causing myocarditis and neuritis.
  • Myocarditis is potentially fatal.

Factors Affecting Production
  • Influenced by environmental factors: alkaline pH (7.8-8.0), oxygen, and iron concentration in the growth medium.
  • High production with low iron availability; iron addition inhibits production.

Toxoid Formation
  • Treatment with formalin (0.2-0.4%), and incubation at 37°C for 4-6 weeks converts DT to toxoid.
  • Toxoid lacks toxicity but induces an immune response; used in vaccines.

Immunity
  • Immunity is primarily mediated by antitoxin antibodies neutralizing DT.

The HIV genome requires which of the following to initiate the process of entering the host cell membrane?
questions.explanation:
Structural Genes (3)

Non-structural Genes (6)

gag Gene: Codes for the virus's core and shell components. The precursor protein p55 is cleaved into:

  • p18: Matrix or shell antigen.
  • p24 and p15: Core antigens.

Essential Regulatory Genes:

  • tat: Transcriptional transactivator. Tat recruits cellular transcription factors to the HIV-1 promoter.
  • nef: Negative factor. Regulatory protein that affects HIV-1 virulence
  • rev: Regulator of virus gene. The HIV-1 Rev protein regulates post-transcriptional processing of viral mRNAs

pol Gene: Codes for viral enzymes, including reverse transcriptase, protease, and integrase. It is expressed as a precursor protein that is cleaved into:

  • p31: Integrase.
  • p51 and p66: Reverse transcriptase.

Accessory Regulatory Genes:

  • vif: Viral infectivity factor.
  • vpr: Involved in viral replication.
  • vpu: Enhances the maturation and release of progeny virus from cells.

env Gene: Codes for the envelope glycoprotein gp160, which is cleaved into:

  • gp120: Main receptor that binds to CD4 on host cells, initiating infection.
  • gp41: Fusion protein facilitating entry into the host cell.

Feature

Cadaveric Spasm

Rigor Mortis

Time of Onset

Immediately after death.

Muscles Involved

Primarily involves voluntary muscles, often limited to a small group (e.g., hand muscles).

Involves both voluntary and involuntary muscles.

Primary Relaxation

Present- muscles initially go through a phase of relaxation.

Molecular Death

Present- ATP depletion causes biochemical changes in muscle fibers.

Electronic Stimuli Response

Absent- muscles do not respond to electrical stimuli after rigor sets in.

Introduction
  • Dried extract from the poppy plant (Papaver somniferum)

Extraction
  • Obtained by vertical incisions from unripe poppy capsule (toxic part)

Toxic principles
  • Phenanthrene group: Morphine, Codeine and Thebaine
  • Benzylisoquinoline group: Papaverine and Noscapine

Mechanism of action (MOA)
  • Exhibits action via 3 receptors mainly - Mu(μ), Delta(δ) and Kappa(κ) receptors and release Endorphins.
  • Addictive potential is due to its action on Mu(μ) and Delta(δ) receptors
  • Action on Kappa(κ) receptor causes dysphoria - no addictive potential

Effects
  • Tolerability, Addiction, Dysphoria (κ-receptor)
  • Pruritus is a common adverse effect.
  • Other effects: Constipation, Respiratory depression, Urinary retention.
  • Tolerability is developed for all actions except: 3 C's
    • Constipation
    • Convulsions
    • Constriction of pupils (Miosis)

Fatal dose

Opium: 2 g

Morphine: 0.2 g

Codeine: 80 mg

Fatal period: 6-12 hours

Management

  • Support vitals: Use a respirator and other emergency procedures.
  • Decontamination:
    • Stomach wash with 1:5000 KMnO₄, leaving some solution in the stomach to oxidize any secreted alkaloid.
    • Perform lavage even after IV/IM drug injection, as it is secreted in the stomach.
    • Administer activated charcoal as the primary decontamination method.
    • Enema with sodium sulfate twice daily.
    • Whole-bowel irrigation for body packers.
  • Antidote:
    • Naloxone

questions.text: All of the following are used in the identification of a dead body except?
questions.explanation:
Samples Collected from Dead Bodies

Fresh Dead Bodies
  • Use unclotted 10 mL blood in a sterile EDTA tube as the preferred DNA source.
  • EDTA buffers inhibit DNA-degrading nucleases.
  • Clotted blood is unsuitable due to WBC settling.

Intermediate Postmortem
  • Brain tissue is a good DNA source.

Advanced Decomposition
  • Hard tissues like bone and teeth (vascular pulp) are ideal for DNA extraction.
  • Recommended materials: muscle, spleen, bone marrow (femur), and molars.
  • Postmortem samples are less reliable due to DNA degradation and putrefaction.

Samples Collected from Living Subjects

Blood
  • Collect 5 mL venous blood in an EDTA vacutainer (purple stopper) and mix gently.
  • Avoid heparin as it interferes with PCR.
  • Preserve at 2–8°C (do not freeze).

Buccal Epithelial Cells
  • Use buccal swabs as a noninvasive, inexpensive, and easy alternative for DNA collection.
  • Swab the mouth for 10 seconds without touching the tip, then place in a receptacle to dry.

Hair Follicles with Roots
  • Pluck 10–20 hairs from the head.
  • Roots contain nuclear DNA; shafts contain mitochondrial DNA.
  • Naturally shed or cut hairs may still provide DNA from nucleated corneocytes.

Samples Encountered in Forensic Practice

Blood

Found as EDTA/heparinized, clotted, or stains on cloth, wood, or tiles.

Semen

Found as stains on cloth, paper, or floors.

Hair

Found on the head, body, or pubic regions.

Tissue

Includes bone marrow, muscle, spleen, or fingernail scrapings.

Saliva

Found on mouth swabs, cigarette butts, envelopes, or glasses.

A 10-year-old boy's father noticed agonal respiration at 5 AM while he was asleep. He was rushed to the ER where an ECG was performed as given. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Brugada Syndrome

About

A rare, inherited disease that predisposes patients to potentially fatal cardiac arrhythmias, characterised by right bundle branch block and ST-segment elevations in the right precordial leads (V1-V3) on ECG.

Clinical features
  • Symptoms range from asymptomatic to sudden cardiac death, often during sleep.
  • Syncope in 80% of patients with ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.
  • Other symptoms: Palpitations, dizziness, and fever history may trigger symptoms.

ECG findings
  • Type I: Coved ST elevations >2 mm with inverted T wave.
  • Type II: Saddleback-shaped ST elevation >2 mm.
  • Type III: Saddleback-shaped ST elevations <2 mm.
  • Patients with a normal ECG and high-risk factors may need a drug challenge test to reveal ST elevations in leads V1 to V3.

Drug challenge test
  • Drugs used in the challenge test:
    • Class IA antiarrhythmics (Procainamide, Ajmaline).
    • IC antiarrhythmics (Flecainide, Propafenone).
  • Brugada ECG findings can also emerge from Cocaine use or Tricyclic antidepressant toxicity.
  • Electrolyte abnormalities like Hyperkalemia and Hypercalcemia can reveal ST elevations in the right precordial leads.
  • A normal drug challenge test in pediatric patients may need to be repeated after puberty due to hormonal influences.
  • The "Full Stomach Test" can also help expose ST elevations by increasing vagal tone.
  • Additional diagnostic options include genetic testing for SCN5A mutations and invasive electrophysiology.

Treatment
  • Implantable Cardioverter-Defibrillator (ICD) for high-risk patients.

A 34-year-woman at 30 weeks of gestation is experiencing vaginal bleeding and pain abdomen. She has drenched her clothes and has experienced reduced fetal movements. On examination, her cervix was 6cm dilated and 50% effaced. Her BP was 150/100 mmHg, PR= 100 bpm. Her abdomen corresponded to 34 weeks, and she had a tense and tender uterus with regular contractions and no fetal heart sounds. Her urine protein was 2,+ and there is no active bleeding. What is the ideal management?
questions.correct_answer: A. Antihypertensives + ARM (artificial rupture of membranes)
questions.explanation:
Vaginal delivery is favoured in:
  1. Limited placental abruption.
  2. FHR tracing is reassuring.
  3. Facilities for continuous fetal monitoring are available.
  4. The prospect of vaginal delivery is soon.
  5. Placental abruption with a dead fetus.

Cesarean section is favoured in: (Option B)
  1. Bleeding continues, and the placental abruption is greater than in Grade 1.
  2. Severe abruption with a live fetus.
  3. An amniotomy could not be done due to an unfavourable cervix.
  4. The prospect of immediate vaginal delivery is remote despite attempts.
  5. Amniotomy failed to control bleeding.
  6. Amniotomy failed to arrest the process of abruption, evidenced by rising fundal height or the appearance of adverse features (e.g., fetal distress, falling fibrinogen level, oliguria).

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida with a low-risk pregnancy presents at 39 weeks + 6 days with labour pains. Her vitals are stable. On PV, her cervix is 3cm dilated and 60% effaced. questions.explanation:
Living baby

Definitive treatment

 

Cesarean Section (Best option for mature, living babies)

If immediate Safe Vaginal Delivery Possible:
  • Head Engaged: Complete delivery with forceps (ventouse is less ideal).
  • Breech Presentation: Complete delivery by breech extraction.

If immediate Safe Vaginal Delivery Not Possible

 
  • Minimise cord pressure until definitive treatment or transfer to a suitable hospital.
  • Stop any ongoing oxytocin infusion.
  • Bladder Filling: Use a Foley catheter to fill the bladder with 400–750 mL fluid—empty the bladder before cesarean delivery.
  • Postural Treatment: Use an elevated Sims position with a pillow or wedge
  • Cord Replacement: Place the cord back into the vagina to reduce vasospasm.

Baby Dead

 

Allow labour to proceed for spontaneous delivery.

questions.text: What is the wrong match? a. Uterine Prolapse 1. Hysterectomy b. Vault prolapse 2. Sacrospinous fixation c. Rectocele 3. Posterior colpoperineorrhaphy d. Cystocele 4. Colposuspension
questions.explanation:
Clinical features
  • Urinary incontinence
  • Pelvic discomfort
  • Anterior vaginal wall prolapse
  • Bulge shows transverse rugosities and impulse on coughing

Management

Surgical: (recommended for women >40 years)

  • Anterior Colporrhaphy: (most preferred)
    • weakened tissue between the bladder and vagina is repaired.
  • Mesh Repair:
    • synthetic mesh is used for additional support.
    • Risk of recurrence, mesh erosion and infection
  • Sacral Colpopexy:
    • Mesh is attached from the top of the vagina to the sacrum to lift the prolapsed organs.
    • High risk of recurrence and complications
  • Vaginal Hysterectomy:
    • Considered in cases where uterine prolapse coexists with cystocele.

Conservative:

  • Recommended in young women with prolapse following childbirth for the initial 4-6 months
  • Pelvic floor exercises

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with high-grade fever for the past week. On examination neck stiffness and Kernig's sign were positive. CSF analysis showed lymphocytosis protein - 8 g/L, glucose - 20 mg/dl while RBS = 140 mg/dl. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Symptoms and Clinical Features:
  • Headache, slight mental changes, and low-grade fever can develop over weeks, often accompanied by malaise, anorexia, and irritability.
  • More severe cases present with confusion, lethargy, neck rigidity, and altered sensorium.
  • Disease progression: evolves over 1–2 weeks, longer than bacterial meningitis.
  • Cranial nerve palsies, especially ocular nerves, are common due to inflammation at the base of the brain.
  • May result in coma, hydrocephalus, and intracranial hypertension if untreated.
  • Cerebral ischemia can result from the involvement of cerebral arteries.
  • Tuberculoma (space-occupying lesion) may cause seizures and focal neurological signs.

CSF Findings:
  • Elevated leukocyte count (up to 1000/μL, predominantly lymphocytes).
  • High protein content (1-8 g/L).
  • Low glucose concentration.

Investigation of Choice:
  • Culture of CSF (gold standard, takes 4-8 weeks, positive in ~50%).
  • Smear for acid-fast bacilli (AFB) (low sensitivity, positive in 10-40%).
  • PCR for Mycobacterium tuberculosis DNA (variable sensitivity).

Imaging:
  • CT/MRI may show hydrocephalus and abnormal enhancement of basal cisterns or ependyma.
  • Tuberculomas appear as contrast-enhanced ring lesions on imaging.

MRI showing ring-enhanced lesions- tuberculoma

Treatment:
  • Empirical therapy is often initiated based on suspicion.
  • Initial drug regimen: Isoniazid, Rifampin, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol, and Pyridoxine.
  • Duration: 6–12 months depending on response.
  • Dexamethasone (12–16 mg/day) for 3 weeks, tapered for 3 more weeks (recommended for HIV-negative patients).
  • Tuberculoma may require a biopsy for diagnosis.

vWD type 1

  • Autosomal dominant.
  • The most common type.
  • Mild to moderate vWF deficiency.
  • Quantitative defect.
  • Point substitutions prevent the vWF protein from maturing or cause it to leave the plasma quickly.

 
  • Autosomal dominant.

Types: 2A, 2B, 2M, 2N

  • 2A (Most common) - Decrease in binding between vWF and Gp1b/9 Missense mutations cause faulty multimer formation → the most active forms of vWF, i.e. large- and intermediate-sized multimers are absent.
  • 2B - Increase in binding between vWF and Gp1b/9
  • 2M - VWF-dependent platelet adhesion is decreased. VWF binding to platelets is impaired. Type 2M VWD typically has mild to moderate mucocutaneous bleeding
  • 2N - There is a marked decline in the binding affinity for factor VIII. The level of factor VIII is lower when compared to the VWF: Ag. This led to misdiagnosis as haemophilia A.
  • Autosomal recessive.
  • Quantitative defect.
  • Produced by frameshift mutations or deletions affecting both alleles (autosomal recessive), which produce little or no vWF.
  • Factor VIII levels are also lowered because vWF stabilizes factor VIII in the blood, and the resulting bleeding condition is severe.

questions.text: After class switching, a particular class of antibody is produced, but IgM and IgD are expressed concomitantly on the surface of a B cell due to which of the following phenomena?
All of the following are the causes of high-output cardiac failure, except?
questions.explanation:
Causes of high-output cardiac failure

Category

Aetiology

Pathophysiology




 

Metabolic

Hyperthyroidism

Increased thyroid hormone increases contractility, heart rate, and systemic metabolism, causing reduced systemic vascular resistance and eventually cardiomyopathy.

Myeloproliferative disorders

Increased cellular metabolism and turnover, leading to higher metabolic demand and decreased systemic vascular resistance.







 

Myocardial

Sepsis

Inflammatory response leads to vasodilation and high cardiac output; initially hyperdynamic phase with low systemic vascular resistance.

Thiamine deficiency (Beriberi) (Option B)

Thiamine deficiency causes systemic vasodilation and direct myocardial effects, resulting in high venous return and cardiomyopathy.

Chronic lung disease

Chronic hypoxia and hypercapnia reduce systemic arterial resistance, causing chronic volume overload and right-sided heart failure.





 

Peripheral vascular

Arteriovenous fistulas (AVF) (Option D)

Shunt from artery to vein bypasses the arteriolar and capillary bed, increasing venous return to the heart, and requiring increased cardiac output.

Liver cirrhosis

Impaired clearance of vasoactive substances and bacterial translocation lead to decreased systemic vascular resistance and high-output failure.

Obesity

Excessive vasodilation due to adipokines and altered myocardial metabolism contribute to high-output cardiac failure.







 

Other

Erythroderma

Vasoactive changes that may lead to high-output cardiac failure (less defined).

Carcinoid syndrome

Tumor secretion of vasoactive substances can cause vasodilation and reduced systemic vascular resistance.

Mitochondrial disorders

Altered cellular metabolism and energy production lead to increased demand and potential high-output failure.

Acromegaly

Increased growth hormone can lead to increased tissue demand and altered vascular resistance.

Paget disease of bone

Increased bone turnover leads to AVF formation, contributing to high-output cardiac failure.

Conditions

Stress, exercise, fever, pregnancy

Temporary increases in metabolic demand or vasodilation, though not direct causes of high-output cardiac failure.
 

Anemia (Option C)

The attempt to compensate for reduced oxygen delivery by increasing cardiac output leads to high-output cardiac failure later on.

questions.text: A pregnant female with bipolar disorder came to the outpatient department in the third trimester. She has had 4 episodes in the past and is stable on lithium 750 mg/day since 1 year, during which time she has not had any episodes. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

options.text: Stop lithium and let her be drug-free

questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Decrease lithium dosage:

Mood Stabilizers

Medication

Potential Fetal/Newborn risk

Clinical Recommendation

Lithium

 
  • Low risk of Ebstein’s anomaly: 1 in 1000 with first-trimester exposure
  • No evidence of behavioural or cognitive problems in children exposed to lithium till 5 years of age
  • Fetal echocardiography
  • Frequent serum lithium monitor because of fluid shifts over pregnancy
  • Should be well hydrated to reduce chances of lithium toxicity

Valproic acid

 
  • Increased rate of congenital malformations.
  • Linked to neurodevelopmental disorders in children with in-utero exposure
  • Must be avoided in favor of safer agents
  • Before conception, women with BD preferably to be shifted to another safer prophylactic agent
  • High-dose folic acid supplementation (4 mg/day) is advised before conception

Carbamazepine

 
  • Congenital malformations: Neural tube defect, cleft palate, fingernail hypoplasia.
  • Risk of bleeding diathesis in neonates due to Vitamin K deficiency
  • If possible, use in pregnancy should be avoided.
  • High-dose folic acid supplementation (4 mg/day) advised prior to conception
  • Oral Vitamin K (20mg/day) supplementation in the last month of pregnancy in women taking carbamazepine
  • Parenteral Vitamin K (1mg IM) supplementation for newborn shortly after birth.

Lamotrigine

 
  • Risk of major congenital malformations.
  • No significant neurobehavioral sequelae.
  • Preferred safer agent to use in pregnancy.
  • Dose may be increased due to enhanced clearance rates across pregnancy stages.
Other Drugs for Bipolar Disorder Safe in Pregnancy
  • First Generation Antipsychotics (FGA): Haloperidol, Trifluoperazine
  • Second Generation Antipsychotics (SGA): Olanzapine, quetiapine, aripiprazole
  • Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRI): Fluoxetine, escitalopram, sertraline, fluvoxamine

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of cough, night sweats, and fever. A lung biopsy demonstrates the following histological findings. What is the most likely cytokine involved?

A 30-year-old farmer from Tamil Nadu presented with fever, myalgia, headache and cough. On physical examination, a lesion is seen on the chest. Lung auscultation shows extensive bilateral rales. Blood investigation showed positive IgM for scrub typhus. What would be the appropriate treatment?
questions.explanation:
Causative agent
  • Orientia tsutsugamushi, an intracellular bacterium.

 

Transmission

  • Bites of infected larval stage mites (chiggers).
  • These are often found in rural areas, forests, and grasslands.


 

Clinical features

  • Fever
  • Headache
  • Muscle pain
  • Eschar: Blackish scab at the site of the chigger bite
  • Rash
  • Lymphadenopathy

 

Diagnosis

  • Serology: Detection of antibodies in blood
  • PCR: Molecular detection of the bacterium












 

Management

Recent update:

  • According to a recent update, combination therapy with IV doxycycline and Azithromycin is more effective than monotherapy.

Doxycycline: (Option A)

  • First-line treatment for scrub typhus.
  • Administered at 100 mg IV or orally, twice daily for 7 to 14 days.
  • Concerns about potential doxycycline resistance in some cases.

Azithromycin:

  • Alternative to Doxycycline, especially if resistance is suspected.
  • Shorter treatment duration
  • Effective penetration into key immune cells (polymorphonuclear leukocytes and macrophages) enhances efficacy.

Rifampicin:

  • A second-line option, not first-line.
  • Risk of inducing resistant tuberculosis so should be used cautiously after ruling out active tuberculosis.

questions.text: Which of the following will increase in size on electrophoresis in Nephrotic syndrome?
A 21 year old boxer wanted to improve the vision . Which of the following surgery is contraindicated?
questions.explanation:
Refractive surgeries for myopia

Incisional Method

Radial Keratotomy (RK)
  • Involves radial cuts in the cornea to flatten it, correcting myopia.
  • Used for low to moderate myopia (2-6 D).
  • No longer recommended due to the advent of safer procedures like LASIK.

Newer Methods

Photorefractive Keratectomy (PRK)

(Option B ruled out)
  • It uses an excimer laser to reshape the cornea by removing a thin corneal layer.
  • Suitable for correcting myopia up to -6 D.

Refractive Lenticule Extraction (SMILE):

(Option D ruled out)
  • A minimally invasive laser procedure where a small lenticule is removed to reshape the cornea.
  • Effective for myopia up to -10 D, with or without astigmatism.

Intercorneal Rings (ICR):
  • Rings are inserted into the cornea to flatten it and reduce refractive power.
  • Results can be unpredictable, with risks such as corneal inflammation, so is not recommended

Orthokeratology
  • A non-surgical and reversible method involving rigid contact lenses worn overnight to reshape the cornea.
  • Corrects myopia up to -5 D temporarily.

High Myopia Solutions

Clear Lens Extraction
  • Removal of the natural lens (without cloudiness) to correct very high myopia (-16 D to -18 D).
  • Less common now due to risks like retinal detachment.

Phakic Intraocular Lens (IOL) Implantation

 
  • Implantable lens placed without removing the natural lens.
  • Best for myopia exceeding -8 D, especially in patients unsuitable for laser surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in very severe NPDR?
questions.explanation:
Severity

Definition

Very mild nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy

Microaneurysms only

Mild nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy

Microaneurysms plus hard exudates, cotton-wool spots, and/or mild retinal hemorrhages

Moderate nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy

Microaneurysms plus mild intraretinal microvascular abnormalities or moderate retinal hemorrhages

Severe nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy

Any one of the following (4-2-1 Rule)

  • Severe retinal hemorrhages in four quadrants
  • Venous beading in at least two
  • Moderately severe intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA) in at least one quadrant

Very severe nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy

Any two of the following (4-2-1 Rule)

  • Severe retinal hemorrhages in four quadrants (Option C ruled out)
  • Venous beading in at least two (Option A ruled out)
  • Moderately severe intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA) in at least one quadrant (Option D ruled out)

Early NPDR or Background Diabetic Retinopathy

Severe NPDR or Preproliferative Diabetic Retinopathy
  • Affects small retinal vessels.
  • Earliest sign: Microaneurysm
    • Fluorescein angiography (FA): Tiny hyperfluorescent dots.
  • Retinal hemorrhages: Both deep, i.e., in the inner nuclear or outer plexiform layer (dot and blot hemorrhage) and superficial, i.e., in nerve fiber layer (splinter or flame-shaped) hemorrhages
  • Hard exudates:
    • White or yellow waxy patches with well-defined margins, often at the posterior pole, in the outer plexiform layer.
    • FA: Hypofluorescence with dense exudates.
  • Edema is not marked.
  • Increased inner retinal hypoxia: Leads to multiple retinal hemorrhages, cotton-wool spots, venous beading, vascular loops, intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMAs), and large areas of capillary nonperfusion.
  • Cotton-Wool Spots:
    • Also called soft exudates or nerve fiber infarcts.
    • Result from ischemia, not exudation.
    • Caused by obstruction of axoplasmic flow, leading to swelling and a white, fluffy appearance.
    • FA: Focal hypofluorescence due to local ischemia.
  • Venous Beading:
    • Indicates sluggish retinal circulation.
    • Typically adjacent to large areas of capillary nonperfusion. (Option D)
  • Intraretinal Microvascular Abnormalities (IRMA):
    • Dilated capillaries act as collateral channels.
    • Bypass capillary bed and is often seen adjacent to capillary nonperfusion.
    • FA: Focal hypofluorescence

questions.text: What does the ECG depict in the following image?
questions.explanation:
Second-degree heart block

Dropped beats occur because some impulses from the atria fail to be transmitted to the ventricles.

Types

Mobitz Type I (Wenckebach)

Mobitz Type II

Description
  • Progressive lengthening of PR intervals until a dropped beat occurs.
  • Cycle repeats itself.
  • PR interval remains constant.
  • Some P waves are not conducted.

Clinical Features
  • Often physiological; can occur in young athletes.
  • May not cause symptoms.
  • Caused by His-Purkinje system disease.
  • Higher risk of asystole.

Management
  • Typically does not require treatment.
  • Monitor for changes; consider underlying heart disease.
  • May require treatment if symptomatic.
  • Consider temporary pacing.
  • Monitor closely due to the risk of progression.

questions.text: A patient on a mood stabilizer has developed hyperammonemia and hepatitis /raised hepatic enzymes. Which of the following is likely to be responsible?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Valproate:

Mechanism of action

  • Sodium Channel Inactivation: Prolongs Na+ channel inactivation in a frequency-dependent manner, similar to phenytoin.
  • Calcium Channel Modulation: Weakly attenuates the T-type calcium currents, akin to ethosuximide.
  • GABA Enhancement: Increases GABA levels by:
    • Inhibiting GABA transaminase, leading to reduced degradation.
    • Possibly enhancing GABA synthesis from glutamic acid.
  • Glutamate Receptor Blockade: Blocks excitatory NMDA glutamate receptors, reducing excitatory neurotransmission.

Uses

  • Seizure Disorders: It is the DOC for atypical absence seizures, myoclonic seizures, and generalised tonic-clonic seizures (GTCS).
  • Mood Disorders: Valproate is effective in the treatment of mania and bipolar disorder.
  • Panic Attacks: It can be used off-label for the treatment of panic attacks.
  • Migraine Prophylaxis: Valproate is considered a second-line treatment for preventing migraines.
  • Mixed Seizure Syndromes: It is used in conditions such as Lennox-Gastaut syndrome.
  • Severe Myoclonic Epilepsy of Infancy: Valproate is also used in Dravet syndrome

Adverse effects

  • Gastrointestinal: Nausea, vomiting, and indigestion.
  • Neurological: Tremor, sedation, dizziness, and ataxia.
  • Hepatic: Hepatotoxicity (mainly in children <2 years of age).
  • Hematologic: Thrombocytopenia and other blood dyscrasias.
  • Metabolic: Weight gain, hyperammonemia, and pancreatitis.
  • Teratogenicity: Risk of congenital malformations, such as neural tube defects (spina bifida oculta), if used during pregnancy.
  • Others: Hair loss (alopecia) and polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

Valproate is a CYP enzyme inhibitor that inhibits CYP2C9, which can lead to increased levels of drugs metabolised by this enzyme, such as phenytoin and warfarin.

Following instrument is used to measure?
A 75-year-old woman with Type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension, developed features of heart failure and expired. The post-mortem cardiac biopsy slide is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Abnormal Diastolic Function
  • The primary abnormality in restrictive cardiomyopathy is impaired diastolic filling due to the stiffened ventricular walls.
  • Elevated end-diastolic pressures in both ventricles without significant chamber dilation.

Bilateral Atrial Enlargement

The non-compliant ventricles lead to increased pressures, resulting in dilation of both atria.

Right-Sided Heart Failure

The stiff ventricles result in increased filling pressures, particularly affecting the right side, causing peripheral oedema, ascites, and jugular venous distention.

Amyloid Infiltration (in amyloidosis)

Amyloid fibrils (pink hyaline deposits) accumulate between myocytes, leading to myocardial stiffening and restrictive physiology.

Cardiac amyloidosis (Congo red stain)

Fibrosis

In conditions like radiation-induced cardiomyopathy or endomyocardial fibrosis, stiffening of the myocardium occurs due to scarring, further impairing ventricular filling.

questions.text: Iritis is least associated with all of the following diseases:
What is the probable diagnosis based on the observed blanching of vascularity following the administration of 10 % phenylephrine, as depicted in the provided image?
questions.explanation:
Episcleritis

Definition

Episcleritis refers to inflammation of the loose connective tissue between the sclera and the conjunctiva

Etiology

Idiopathic

Systemic diseases - gout, rosacea, psoriasis, and connective tissue diseases.

Hypersensitivity reaction to endogenous tubercular or streptococcal toxins.

Infectious episcleritis - herpes zoster virus, syphilis, Lyme disease, and tuberculosis.

Clinical features
  • Common in young females
  • Acute onset redness
  • Discomfort - gritty/foreign body sensation
  • Mild to no pain
  • Resolves spontaneously
  • Recurrence is common

Clinical types
  1. Simple episcleritis: Sectorial (occasionally diffuse) inflammation of episclera. The engorged episcleral vessels are large and run in a radial direction beneath the conjunctiva
  2. Nodular episcleritis: Pink or purple flat nodule surrounded by injection, usually situated 2-3 mm away from the limbus. The nodule is firm, tender can be moved separately from the sclera and the overlying conjunctiva also moves freely.

Diagnosis

10% Topical phenylephrine blanches overlying conjunctival vessels and inflamed episcleral vessels.

Differential diagnosis
  • Conjunctivitis, which is more superficial; blanching occurs with 2.5% phenylephrine
  • Phlyctenulosis (Option C ruled out)
  • Inflamed pinguecula
  • Scleritis, which is deeper and more painful; does not blanch with 10% phenylephrine (Option B ruled out)

Treatment

  • Topical NSAIDs
  • Topical mild corticosteroid eye drops
  • Topical artificial tears,
  • Cold compresses applied to the closed lids may offer symptomatic relief from ocular discomfort.
  • Systemic NSAIDs

Vascular plexuses

Locations of Vessels

Clinical correlation.

Conjunctival plexus

Most superficial
  • Congested in conjunctivitis.
  • Blanched with topical vasoconstrictor

Superficial episcleral plexus

Lies at the level of Tenon's capsule.

Radial configuration.
  • Congested in episcleritis.
  • Blanched with topical vasoconstrictor.

Deep vascular plexus

Lies deep to the Tenon's capsule and over the sclera.

Criss-cross pattern.
  • Congested in scleritis.
  • Does not blanch with a topical vasoconstrictor.

Which of the following has the least risk of perinatal transmission?
questions.explanation:
Causative Agent

Rubella virus

Transmission

Vertical transmission from mother to fetus during pregnancy; highest risk during the first trimester

Risk Period

Highest fetal risk occurs when the mother contracts rubella in the first trimester

Classical Triad

1. Sensorineural deafness

2. Cataracts

3. Congenital heart disease (commonly patent ductus arteriosus)

Other Clinical Features
  • Salt and pepper retinopathy (speckled retinal appearance)

 

  • Blueberry muffin lesions (bluish-red nodular lesions)
  • Microcephaly
  • Micrognathia
  • Developmental delay
  • Thrombocytopenic purpura
  • Jaundice
  • Hepatosplenomegaly

Diagnosis

Clinical findings and laboratory tests (rubella-specific IgM antibodies, rubella virus RNA detection)

Management

No specific antiviral treatment; prevention through rubella vaccination (MMR) before pregnancy

Complications
  • Developmental delay and cognitive deficits
  • Neurological sequelae (e.g., seizures)
  • Ophthalmic (e.g., cataracts)
  • Cardiac defects (e.g., patent ductus arteriosus)

Prevention

MMR vaccination prior to pregnancy is crucial to avoid CRS

questions.text: A stroke patient presents with an inability to identify objects but can determine the colour, texture, and shape of objects. Which of the following lobes is involved?
questions.explanation:
Features of Left Temporal Lobe Stroke

Features of Right Temporal Lobe Stroke
  • Impaired language and memory: Difficulty with spoken language and remembering verbal information.
  • Fluent (Wernicke’s) aphasia: Fluent speech with incorrect words, affecting language comprehension.
  • Poor visual memory and spatial awareness: Difficulty recognizing visual patterns and spatial information.
  • Prosopagnosia: Inability to recognize faces, including familiar ones.

General Features of Temporal Lobe Stroke
  • Poor memory: Difficulty recalling memories and learning new information.
  • Prosopagnosia: Trouble recognizing faces and objects.
  • Fluent aphasia: Specifically in left-sided strokes, affecting speech fluency but with incorrect word use.
  • Visual perception difficulties: Challenges with interpreting the visual field and surroundings.
  • Trouble processing sound: Inability to differentiate or process sounds correctly.
  • Visual agnosia: Inability to recognize visually presented objects despite otherwise normal visual field, acuity, colour vision, brightness, discrimination, language, and memory.
  • Emotional and behavioural changes: Varying behaviours due to damage to the amygdala, such as aggression, passiveness, or difficulty interpreting facial cues.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic male with central chest pain, shortness of breath and palpitations came to the emergency department. An ECG was taken, which showed NSTEMI. Which of the following is the right treatment?
questions.explanation:
Medical management

Anti-ischemic therapy:

  • Sublingual glyceryl trinitrate/nitroglycerin:
    • DOC for unstable angina
    • For ischemic discomfort
  • IV beta-blockers (Atenolol, Metoprolol):
    • They reduce the oxygen demand of the myocardium
    • They relieve pain, reduce arrhythmias, and reduce short-term mortality
  • Verapamil and diltiazem:
    • Given if symptoms are not relieved by full dose beta blockers and nitrates
    • They decrease the heart rate
  • IV morphine sulfate or diamorphine:
    • For analgesia
  • Antiemetics like metoclopramide (For symptomatic relief)
  • Nifedipine or amlodipine (If chest discomfort persists)
  • Atorvastatin and other HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors: Reduces occurrence of MI and recurrences of acute coronary syndrome
  • Ezetimibe or alirocumab, evolocumab:
    • Given if unresponsive to full dose statins
    • They reduce LDL cholesterol and prevent further cardiovascular events

Antithrombotic therapy:

  • Antiplatelet drugs:
    • Cyclooxygenase inhibitor: Aspirin
    • Platelet P2Y12 receptor inhibitor: Clopidogrel

Anticoagulants:

  • Unfractionated heparin.
  • Low molecular heparin: Enoxaparin.
  • Direct thrombin inhibitor: Bivalirudin.
  • Synthetic factor Xa inhibitor: Fondaparinux.

Invasive management
  • Done if the medical management fails and symptoms do not improve.
  • Coronary arteriography must be done within 48 hours of presentation.
  • Coronary revascularization includes PCI (percutaneous coronary intervention) or coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).

questions.explanation:
Modified Duke’s Criteria - Major criteria
 

Positive blood cultures
  • Identification of a typical organism from two cultures, or persistent positive cultures drawn more than 12 hours apart.
  • Three or more positive cultures that have been taken over at least 1hour apart. (Option B)
  • A single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetii or a phase I IgG antibody titre > 1:800.
 

Evidence of endocardial involvement
  • Positive echocardiographic findings such as vegetations, abscesses, or new valvular regurgitation.
  • Oscillating intracardiac masses or partial dehiscence of a prosthetic valve.
  • Additional diagnostic tools like FDG-PET/CT or EKG-gated cardiac CT angiograms also meet major criteria for prosthetic valve endocarditis. (Added by the European Society of Cardiology)

A 6-year-old boy was brought in with a history of chronic cough and foul-smelling stools. His sibling, who had similar complaints, died a few years back. Sweat chloride test and CFTR gene studies were done. CFTR gene codes for proteins involved in the transport of
questions.explanation:
Genetic Basis
  • Gene: CFTR (Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator)
  • Location: Chromosome 7q31.2
  • Common Mutation: ΔF508
  • Inheritance: Autosomal recessive

Pathophysiology

 

  • CFTR Dysfunction: Defective chloride transport, increased sodium absorption, dehydrated mucus
  • Metabolic: (Hypokalemia) Due to excessive loss of potassium through sweat and impaired renal potassium handling
  • Respiratory: Airway obstruction, bacterial colonization, bronchiectasis, respiratory failure
  • Gastrointestinal: Pancreatic duct obstruction, malabsorption, Distal Intestinal Obstruction Syndrome
  • Sweat Glands: Salty sweat
  • Reproductive:

Infertility in males: Congenital absence of the vas deferens in males leading to azoospermia and infertility.

Infertility in females: Defective CFTR in the cervix leads to the production of thick, dehydrated cervical mucus that blocks the cervical os, impairing sperm entry and reducing fertility.

Clinical Features
  • Respiratory: Chronic productive cough, recurrent infections, bronchiectasis
  • Gastrointestinal: Steatorrhea, malabsorption, meconium ileus, failure to thrive
  • Genitourinary: Infertility (males), delayed puberty
  • Other: Digital clubbing, salt-loss syndromes (Contraction alkalosis)

Diagnosis

Diagnostic Criteria

Requirement 1: Any ONE of the following

 

  • Clinical Features: Presence of typical features
  • Family History: A sibling with diagnosed cystic fibrosis
  • Newborn Screening: Positive result indicating risk for CF
  • IRT Screening: Elevated Immunoreactive Trypsinogen (IRT) for pancreatic insufficiency

Requirement 2: At least ONE of the following

Laboratory Evidence:

 

  • Sweat Chloride Test: Two elevated sweat chloride concentrations on separate days ≥60 mMol/L (Pilocarpine iontophoresis method)
  • CFTR Mutations: Identification of two CFTR mutations
  • Nasal Potential Difference: Abnormal measurement

Microbes
  • <18 years: Staphylococcus aureus
  • >18 years: Pseudomonas aeruginosa

 

  • Burkholderia cepacia: High mortality, low incidence

Management Strategies
  • Airway Clearance: Chest physiotherapy, percussion, postural drainage
  • Infection Control: Antibiotics, CFTR modulators
  • Nutritional Support:
  • High-calorie diet,
  • Pancreatic Enzyme Replacement Therapy
  • Vitamin supplementation (A, D, E, K)
  • Other: Insulin for CFRD, bone health management

Advanced Therapies
  • CFTR Modulators: Ivacaftor, lumacaftor, Trikafta
  • Trikafta: Elexacaftor-Tezacaftor-Ivacaftor (≥2 years old), improves lung function, reduces sweat chloride

arthropathy: Arthritis/arthralgia, more common in adults

Disease

Staphylococcus aureus or unknown

Rare; characterized by mild rash and fever.

Parvovirus B19

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with a history of fever, conjunctival congestion, and erythematous desquamation of the skin. A 2D echocardiogram shows coronary aneurysms. What is the first-line treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Etiology and Pathophysiology
  • Higher incidence in children of Asian descent.
  • Vasculitis affecting medium-sized arteries, especially coronary arteries.

Pathology

Acute Phase (Days 1-10):

  • Neutrophilic inflammation of blood vessels.
  • Infiltration of inflammatory cells, vessel wall swelling and damage.

 

Subacute Phase (Weeks 2-4): Risk of fusiform aneurysm formation as inflammation subsides.

 

Convalescent Phase (Weeks >4 weeks): Resolution of inflammation; potential scarring and thickening of arterial walls leading to stenosis.

Clinical Features

 
  • Fever: For at least 5 days.
  • Extremities: Swelling, redness, peeling skin around nails, fingers, and toes.
  • Mucocutaneous: Bilateral conjunctivitis, red and cracked lips, "strawberry tongue," and pharyngeal congestion.
  • Polymorphous Rash: Various forms (macular, papular, target-like lesions).
  • Cervical Lymphadenopathy: Unilateral, painful swelling of neck lymph nodes.

Diagnosis

Clinical Criteria:

 

Fever lasting at least 5 days.

 

At least 4 of the following:

 

5-“CREAM” features

 

  • C - Conjunctivitis, B/L non-purulent
  • R - Rash involving trunk
  • E- Erythema & Edema of palms & soles along with desquamation
  • A - Adenopathy (usually unilateral, cervical)
  • M- Mucositis (Strawberry Tongue)

 

Laboratory Findings:

  • Elevated CRP and ESR.
  • Elevated WBC count.
  • Echocardiography coronary artery aneurysms.

Complications
  • Myocardial infarction.
  • Coronary Artery Aneurysms.
  • Coronary Artery Stenosis:

Differential Diagnosis

Bacterial Infections (e.g., Scarlet Fever, Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome): Fever, rash, mucosal involvement with additional features like sore throat or blistering.

Treatment
  • Intravenous Immunoglobulin (IVIG): Reduces inflammation and lowers risk of aneurysms.
  • Aspirin: High doses initially to reduce inflammation and fever; then low-dose regimen for anti-platelet effects.

 

IVIG-Resistant KD:

  • Second dose of IVIG, corticosteroids, or other immunosuppressive medications (e.g., infliximab, cyclosporine).

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with Down's syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Cause
  • Trisomy 21 due to meiotic nondisjunction.
  • Less commonly caused by Robertsonian translocation (4%) or mosaicism (1%).

Incidence

1:800 to 1:1000 live births.

General Features

Craniofacial:

  • Intellectual disability, flat facial profile, upward-slanting eyes, epicanthic folds.
  • Small nose, flat nasal bridge, narrow palate, small teeth, protruding tongue.
  • Brachycephaly, flat occiput, dysplastic ears.

 

Extremities:

  • Short, broad hands, clinodactyly (5th finger), simian crease, sandal gap (wide space between toes).

Comorbidities

Cardiac: 40-60% have congenital heart defects (mainly AVSD, VSD, PDA, ASD).

Gastrointestinal: Duodenal atresia, Hirschsprung disease, annular pancreas.

Hematological: Increased risk of leukemia (acute lymphoblastic leukemia, acute myeloid leukemia).

Endocrine: Thyroid dysfunction (hypothyroidism), type 1 diabetes risk.

Neurological: Early-onset Alzheimer’s disease (APP gene on chromosome 21).

Musculoskeletal: Atlanto-occipital subluxation, short stature, hypotonia, growth delays, obesity risk.

Sensory: Hearing loss (conductive, often due to serous otitis media), ophthalmic problems (cataracts, strabismus, nystagmus).

Diagnosis

Prenatal:

  • Chorionic Villus Sampling (CVS): Performed between 10-13 weeks.
  • Amniocentesis: Performed after 15 weeks.

Postnatal:

  • Characteristic features (e.g., craniofacial dysmorphisms).
  • Confirmatory Test: Karyotype analysis for trisomy 21.

Antenatal Screening

First Trimester: Increased nuchal translucency (>3 mm), elevated β-HCG, low PAPP-A.

Second Trimester: Triple Test (β-HCG, estriol, AFP), Quadruple Test (adds Inhibin-A).

Integrated Test: Combines maternal age, NT, PAPP-A, and Quadruple Test.

Non-Invasive Prenatal Testing (NIPS/NIPT): Cell-free fetal DNA testing (high sensitivity and specificity).

questions.explanation:
Protease inhibitors (PI): (-navir-)

MOA
  • Inhibits the assembly/packaging of viral proteins
  • Competitively inhibits the action of HIV aspartyl protease

Pharmacokinetics

All are CYP3A4 inhibitors: [Except Nelfinavir (CYP2C9)]

  • Simvastatin: Risk of myopathy
  • Midazolam: Causes respiratory depression

Uses

HIV treatment and 2nd line Post-exposure prophylaxis

Drugs: RAFTISLAND
  • Ritonavir
    • Maximum CYP inhibition → inhibits metabolism of other PI
    • Low-dose ritonavir boosts other protease inhibitors (Lopinavir)
  • Amprenavir
  • Fos-amprenavir
  • Tipranavir
  • Indinavir
  • Saquinavir (least CYP inhibitor)
  • Lopinavir
  • Atazanavir (no dyslipidemia)
  • Nelfinavir
  • Darunavir (maximum bioavailability, taken with food)

Side effects

  • Lipodystrophy
  • Indinavir is a protease inhibitor associated with developing nephrolithiasis
  • Tipranavir can cause altered mental status, headache, intracranial bleeding and hepatotoxicity.
  • Ritonavir causes gastrointestinal disturbances, hyperlipidemia, hepatotoxicity.
  • Atazanavir causes Indirect hyperbilirubinemia (jaundice).
  • Darunavir causes rash, liver function abnormalities, gastrointestinal disturbances

Resistance
  • P-glycoprotein efflux transporter
  • Cross-resistance with other protease inhibitors.

questions.text: Which of the following antibiotics acts by inhibiting the 50s ribosome?
questions.explanation:
Linezolid

Aspect

Description

Mechanism of Action
  • It inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 23S ribosomal RNA of the 50S ribosomal subunit.
  • It interferes with the formation of the ternary N-formylmethionyl-tRNA (tRNAf-Met)-70S initiation complex, preventing the initiation of protein synthesis.

Spectrum of Activity
  • Gram-positive cocci (aerobic and anaerobic): MRSA, VRSA, VRE, Strep. viridans, Strep. pneumoniae
  • Other sensitive bacteria: Clostridia, B. fragilis, M. tuberculosis.

Common Uses
  • Uncomplicated and complicated skin and soft tissue infections Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAPs)
  • Bacteremia.

Side Effects
  • Mild abdominal pain, nausea and diarrhoea.
  • Chorioretinitis
  • Optic neuritis
  • Bone marrow suppression (monitor platelet count)
  • Caution is advised when used concurrently with MAO inhibitors due to the risk of serotonin syndrome.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presents with several purpuric skin lesions and is diagnosed with idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura. Which of the following tyrosine kinase inhibitors can be used in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP)

Definition

Autoimmune disorder is characterized by a low platelet count (thrombocytopenia) due to immune system destruction of platelets.

Types

Acute ITP: Typically occurs in children and often follows a viral infection.

Chronic ITP: Persistent low platelet count, lasting more than 12 months, can affect both children and adults.

Clinical features

Petechiae and purpura (bruising) on the skin (easy bruising and bleeding), especially from mucous membranes (spontaneous nosebleeds).

Diagnosis

Blood tests: Platelet count, peripheral blood smear

Management

  • Observation for mild cases without bleeding symptoms
  • 1st Line Treatment: Corticosteroids
  • 2nd Line Therapies: IVIG (intravenous immunoglobulin)
  • Anti-D immunoglobulin (Rho(D) immuno globulin)
  • Thrombopoietin receptor agonists (eltrombopag, romiplostim).
  • Splenectomy (severe or refractory cases)

Complications

Severe bleeding, especially intracranial hemorrhage in rare cases - Impaired quality of life due to bleeding symptoms.

Aspect

Abdominal Rectopexy

Perineal Rectopexy

Types

  • Suture rectopexy- Lahaut
  • Anterior Resection
  • Resection Rectopexy
  • Mucosal sleeve resection (Delrome's) (Option D)
  • Perineal recto sigmoidectomy (Altemeier's) (Option A)
  • Posterior fixation of the rectum of Lockhardt-Mummery
  • Mickulicz Miles perineal transanal recto sigmoidectomy
  • Anal encircling (Thiersch) (Option C)

Advantages
  • Fixation of the rectum provides adequate tension to prevent recurrence.
  • Minimally invasive options (laparoscopic or robotic) offer benefits in pain control, hospital stay, and recovery time
  • Lower operative morbidity and mortality, suitable for elderly or medically unfit patients.

 

Disadvantages
  • Requires extensive dissection and fixation, which may have higher morbidity (10%-33%).
  • Risk of mesh-related complications such as erosion, infection, bowel obstruction, and migration.
  • Higher recurrence rates compared to abdominal approaches

questions.text: A patient presents with swelling in the floor of the mouth. Upon examination, the swelling appears as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ranula

Definition

Ranulas are a type of extravasation mucocele caused by the rupture of the main duct or obstructed acini of the sublingual gland. They appear as bluish swellings on the floor of the mouth and resemble the belly of a frog.

Location
  • Commonly found in the anterior floor of the mouth.
  • When it extends through the mylohyoid muscle, it presents as a submental swelling known as a "plunging ranula."

Symptoms

Typically soft, fluctuant, and painless unless infected.

Diagnosis
  • Confirmed through Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)
  • Ultrasound
  • Aspiration of thick, sticky saliva differentiates it from a lymphangioma.

Treatment
  • Removal of the sublingual gland is preferred.
  • Incision, drainage, and marsupialisation have low success rates. Although marsupialisation is often adequate, it has a higher recurrence rate compared to sublingual gland excision.
  • OK-432 injection
  • Botulinum toxin injections

Image

Description

Rampley's Sponge Holding Forceps

(Option B)

  • Designed in a scissor-like configuration, featuring ratcheted handles with serrated looped jaws.
  • Used to handle gauze or sponges.
  • Used to hold gall bladder/cervix/tongue etc., during operative procedures.

Kocher’s Forceps

(Option C)
  • Serrations in the distal blades with an opposing tooth at the tip.
  • Holds tissues or pedicles securely, preventing slippage and retraction of vessels or bleeders.
  • Types:
    • Straight/Curved.
    • Small/medium/large.
  • Used in thyroidectomy, hemorrhoidectomy, mastectomy, polypectomy, and hysterectomy.

  • Used to hold skin and tough structures like fascia and aponeurosis.
  • Not used for delicate structures like the bowel, vessels, or nerves.
  • May have one-in-two or two-in-three teeth.
  • Adson’s Forceps (Option D): Small, fine forceps for delicate work; can be toothed or non-toothed.

 

  • Victor–Bonney’s Forceps: Heavy-toothed dissecting forceps.

    • Anteriorly: Transverse colon, transverse mesocolon, stomach.
    • Posteriorly: Left psoas major, left sympathetic chain, left renal artery.
    • Superiorly: Body of pancreas.
    • To the left: Left kidney, left ureter.

questions.text: What is the primary prognostic factor that significantly influences the outcome of breast cancer?
questions.explanation:
Disease factors that influence prognosis

Histologic Subtypes
  • Invasive Ductal Carcinoma (IDC): Prognosis varies by grade and molecular markers.
  • Invasive Lobular Carcinoma (ILC): Intermediate prognosis.
  • Tubular and Mucinous Carcinomas: Best prognosis.
  • Basal-like Breast Cancer: Aggressive, triple-negative, no targeted treatments.
  • Other Subtypes: Medullary, cribriform, papillary, adenoid cystic, and metaplastic carcinomas vary in prognosis.

Tumor Size & Lymph Node
  • Pathologic staging (tumour size, lymph nodes) guides prognosis and treatment.
  • Larger tumours and positive lymph nodes = worse prognosis

Molecular Markers
  • Hormone Receptors (ER, PR): ER-positive = better prognosis, responsive to endocrine therapy.
  • HER-2 Status: HER-2 positive = aggressive but treatable with targeted therapies.

Patient factors that influence prognosis

Age

Younger, particularly premenopausal women, may have higher local recurrence rates post-surgery, but radiation therapy can reduce this risk.

BRCA Mutation

Generally more aggressive and associated with poorer prognosis.

Family History

A strong family history may indicate inherited susceptibility and potentially a worse prognosis.

Prior Breast Cancer History

Previous breast cancer can negatively influence the prognosis of a new diagnosis.

Lifestyle Factors

Obesity and inactivity are linked to increased recurrence risk and may affect overall prognosis.

Treatment Adherence

Non-compliance can worsen prognosis.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the image shown below?
questions.explanation:
Increased GH

GH Deficiency

Aspect

Acromegaly (Option B)

Gigantism (Option A ruled out)

Pituitary Dwarfism (Option D ruled out)

Aetiology
  • Hypersecretion of GH after the fusion of the epiphysis
  • Tumor of somatotrophs of the anterior pituitary
  • Often associated with increased prolactin
  • Extra-pituitary causes (e.g., hypothalamic tumours)
  • Increased GH secretion before the closure of epiphyses
  • Pituitary tumour of somatotrophs during childhood
  • Hypothalamic tumor causing excess GHRH secretion
  • GH deficiency

Features
  • Enlargement of hands, feet, jaw, facial bones
  • Osteoarthritis, glucose intolerance, hirsutism
  • Gynecomastia, lactation, visual field changes (bitemporal hemianopia)
  • Visceromegaly, macroglossia, increased heel pad thickness
  • Headache due to enlarged sella turcica and optic chiasma compression
  • Abnormally tall stature due to epiphyseal growth of long bones
  • Features similar to acromegaly except acromegalic facies
  • Short stature, delayed bone, and sexual maturation
  • Decreased muscle and total body mass
  • Decreased cardiac function and bone density
  • Normal mental power (differentiates from thyroid dwarfism)

Management
  • Clinical presentation
  • CT scan or MRI for tumour
  • High GH level in plasma
  • Surgical removal of the tumour
  • Clinical presentation
  • CT scan or MRI for tumour
  • High GH level in plasma
  • Surgical removal of the tumour

questions.text: Which of the following statements is/are true regarding the mechanism by which PTH elevates blood calcium levels?
questions.explanation:
Factor

Description

Effect on Calcium Levels

PTH
  • A hormone secreted by the parathyroid glands in response to low extracellular calcium levels.

Increases

Bone Resorption

  • PTH stimulates osteoblasts, which signal osteoclasts to break down bone tissue, releasing calcium and phosphate into the bloodstream. (Option B)

Increases

Renal Excretion

  • PTH increases calcium reabsorption in the renal tubules, reducing calcium loss through urine. (Option A)
  • PTH decreases phosphate reabsorption in the kidneys.

Increases

Intestinal Absorption

  • PTH indirectly enhances calcium and phosphate absorption in the intestines.
  • This active form of vitamin D promotes the formation of calbindin, a calcium-binding protein, in intestinal cells.

Increases

Vitamin D
  • While not directly regulated by PTH, vitamin D plays a crucial role in calcium regulation. Vitamin D must be converted to its active form, 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol, in the kidneys. PTH is essential for this conversion. (Option C)

Increases

questions.text: Blood pressure changes in the radial artery were measured while performing a valsalva maneuver. Which of the following is the reason for the initial rise in blood pressure?
questions.explanation:
Valsalva Maneuver

Phase I (onset of strain)
  • There is a transient increase in blood pressure that lasts for a few seconds.
  • This occurs due to increased intrathoracic pressure adding to the aortic pressure.

Phase II (phase of straining)
  • Venous return initially decreases, lowering cardiac output and blood pressure for 4 seconds.
  • Later, blood pressure returns to normal due to increased peripheral resistance from sympathetic vasoconstriction.
  • Heart rate steadily increases due to vagal withdrawal and sympathetic activation.

Phase III
  • This phase occurs following the release of strain characterized by a transient decrease in blood pressure lasting for a few seconds.
  • This is caused by the mechanical displacement of blood to the pulmonary vascular bed, which was under increased intrathoracic pressure.
  • There is little change in heart rate.

Phase IV
  • Occurs after further release of strain; blood pressure slowly increases, and heart rate decreases for about a minute.
  • This is due to an increase in venous return, stroke volume, and cardiac output.

questions.text: A patient presented with fever and eschar (as shown in the image below). What will be the treatment?
questions.explanation:
Scrub typhus

Causative agent 

Orientia tsutsugamushi (bacteria)

Transmission 

Chiggers (larval mites)

Vector 

Trombiculid mite (Leptotrombidium)

Geographical distribution 

Endemic in the “tsutsugamushi triangle” (parts of Asia, Australia, Pacific Islands).

Clinical manifestations

Fever, headache, muscle pain, eschar (dark, scab-like lesion at the site of bite), and lymphadenopathy.

Diagnosis 

Serological tests (ELISA, immunofluorescence) and molecular methods (PCR).

Treatment 

Antibiotics (Doxycycline, Azithromycin)

Prevention 

Avoid mite-infested areas, wearing protective clothing, and using insect repellants.

Complications 

Organ failure, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), neurological complications.
